snippet: A theory from an influential paper from the 1950s about the limits of short-term memory has been refined, but not supplanted.
abstract: Cognitive scientist George A Miller's theory, introduced in 1956 paper, that the brain can only hold seven pieces of information in short-term memory has been refined according to several factors.
lead_paragraph: A theory from an influential paper from the 1950s about the limits of short-term memory has been refined, but not supplanted.

headline.main: Seven Isn’t the Magic Number for Short-Term Memory
